On Thursday 26 May 2005 15:53, Elliotte Harold wrote:

> Complicated sequences of code execution are relics of procedural
> thinking. 

It is no more, and no less, easy to have "Complicated sequences of 
code execution" in an OO context than in a non-OO context. OO is
all about managing state by ordering updates.

> In object oriented programming we pass messages to objects. We
> may send any message to any object at any time. Which messages we send
> when depends on what we want the objects to do. However, good objects
> behave according to spec regardless of the order in which the methods
> are invoked. They do not say some method sequences are legal and some
> are illegal. 

All true (if somewhat metaphorical).

> This is because the classes and objects are the fundamental
> units, not the functions and algorithms.

I hardly think so. 

> This is the difference between
> object oriented programming and procedural programming.

It's *a* difference between OO procedural programming and non-OO
procedural programming, I'll grant you.

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct 
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
